The WORST CASE SCENARIO involves a catastrophic release of the entire fifteen tons of chlorine over a ten minute period.  The toxic liquid is assumed to form a large pool of one centimeter in depth from which evaporation would take place.  The earthen dikes around the chlorine building are a passive mitigation measure and were considered in this scenario.  Assuming a release rate of 1650 pounds per minute, class F atmospheric stability, a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second, and an urban topography, a distance of 3.8 miles is reached before obtaining a toxic endpoint of .0087 mg/L (3ppm).  

The chlorine ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO involves the rupture of a single cylinder valve on a one ton cylinder stored near the dual manifold system.  The valve was damaged in transit and was finally broken while being unloaded from the vendor's truck.  The chlorine release cannot be mitigated as nearby employees have had to vacate the immediate area.  The entire contents of the one-ton cylinder is released over a ten-minute period.  Assuming a release rate of 220 pounds per minute, class D atmospheric stability, a wind speed of 3 meters per second, and an urban topography, a distance of .2 miles is reached before obtaining a toxic endpoint of .0087 mg/L (3ppm).

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS;
The District has taken steps necessary to maintain compliance with the accidental release prevention requirements required by 40 CFR Part 68 (Environment).  The currently facility was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable local, state, and federal codes in existance at that time.
